subject: Data
title: Relative Risk vs. Absolute Risk
description: A 60-second lesson on Relative Risk vs. Absolute Risk.

hook.text: 'This drug reduces heart attack risk by 50%!' Sounds amazing â€” until you learn the actual numbers.

buildup.text: The risk went from 2 in 1,000 to 1 in 1,000. Relatively, that's 50%. Absolutely, that's 0.1%.

discovery.text: Relative risk amplifies perception. Absolute risk gives the actual magnitude. Both are mathematically correct.

twist.text: Drug companies consistently use relative risk in marketing because it sounds more impressive.

climax.text: Knowing to ask 'what's the absolute difference?' is one of the most valuable data literacy skills.

punchline.text: A 50% reduction can mean almost nothing in absolute terms.

quiz.question: Why do drug companies prefer reporting relative risk?
options: It makes small benefits sound much larger
